definitions: A push or pull on an object
Something that can make objects move, stop, or change direction
A strength or energy that causes motion or change
The ability to do work or cause change
What makes things move, heat up, or light up
Power that can be changed from one form to another
When a force moves an object over a distance
Force multiplied by the distance moved in the force's direction
Energy transferred when something is moved
How fast work is done or energy is used
Work divided by time, measured in watts
The rate of transferring energy
The state of changing position over time
When an object is moving from one place to another
Movement of an object
How fast an object moves
Distance traveled divided by time taken
The rate of movement
Speed in a specific direction
How fast something moves and which way it goes
Speed with direction included
How quickly velocity changes over time
When an object speeds up, slows down, or changes direction
The rate of change in speed
The amount of matter in an object
How much 'stuff' makes up an object
A measure of an object's resistance to acceleration
The force of gravity pulling on an object's mass
How heavy something is, measured in newtons
Mass multiplied by gravitational force
The force that pulls objects toward each other
What makes things fall down to the ground
The natural force of attraction between masses
A force that opposes motion between two touching surfaces
What makes it hard to slide things across the floor
Resistance when one surface rubs against another
Force spread out over an area
How much force is applied per unit of surface
Force divided by the area it acts on
How much mass is packed into a given volume
Mass per unit volume of a material
How heavy something is for its size
A measure of how hot or cold something is
The average kinetic energy of particles in a substance
Degrees that show thermal energy level
Energy that flows from hotter objects to colder ones
Thermal energy transferred between objects
The movement of energy due to temperature differences
Vibrations that travel through air and can be heard
Energy waves we hear with our ears
Mechanical waves caused by vibrating objects
A form of energy that lets us see things
Electromagnetic waves visible to the eye
Radiation that travels in straight lines
The flow of electric charges through a material
Energy carried by moving electrons
A form of energy from charged particles
A complete path that allows electricity to flow
A closed loop for electric current to travel through
Components connected so electricity can move
A force that attracts iron and some metals
The power of magnets to pull or push other magnets
Invisible force field around magnets
The distance between two peaks of a wave
How long one complete wave cycle is
The measurement from crest to crest of a wave
How many wave cycles pass a point per second
The number of vibrations or oscillations in a given time
How often a wave repeats itself
The electrical 'push' that makes charges move
Potential difference that drives current in a circuit
Electrical pressure measured in volts
The flow of electric charge through a wire
How much electricity passes a point per second
Rate of electron flow in a circuit
How much a material opposes electric current
What makes it hard for electricity to flow
Opposition to the flow of electric charges
When light or sound waves bounce off a surface
The change in direction of waves at a surface
Waves returning after hitting something
When light bends as it passes through different materials
The bending of waves when entering a new medium
Change in wave direction due to speed change
A curved piece of glass that bends light rays
An object that focuses or spreads out light
Transparent material that changes light direction
A smooth surface that reflects light to form images
Glass with a backing that shows your reflection
A surface that bounces back light waves
How far and in what direction an object has moved
The straight-line change in position from start to finish
A vector that shows distance with direction
A measure of how hard it is to stop a moving object
Mass multiplied by velocity
Quantity that depends on both speed and amount of matter
A change in momentum caused by a force over time
Force multiplied by the time it acts
What happens when a short strong push changes motion
The tendency of an object to keep doing what it's doing
Resistance to change in motion
Heavier objects usually have more inertia
A twisting force that makes objects rotate
How strongly a force tries to turn something
The rotational equivalent of a push or pull
A state where all forces balance and nothing changes
When an object stays still or moves steadily because forces cancel
A stable condition with no net motion change
The point where an object's mass is balanced
A single location that represents the object's overall mass
Where you can imagine all the mass being concentrated
A quantity that describes rotation and is conserved
Depends on how mass is distributed and how fast it spins
The rotational version of linear momentum
How fast something spins and in what direction
The rate of rotation measured in radians per second
Describes rotational speed around an axis
How quickly the rotation speed changes
When a spinning object speeds up or slows down
Rate of change of angular velocity
A measure of how hard it is to change an object's rotation
Depends on mass and how far it is from the rotation axis
The rotational equivalent of mass for spinning objects
Repeated back-and-forth motion
Like a swing moving to and fro
Any motion that repeats over time
A smooth repeating motion like a perfect spring or pendulum
Motion that follows a sine or cosine pattern
When restoring force is proportional to displacement
How big a wave or oscillation is
The maximum distance from the middle position
A measure of wave height or motion size
A disturbance that carries energy through space or a medium
Examples include water waves, sound waves, and light waves
Waves move energy without moving matter far distances
When waves bend around obstacles or through small openings
Causes spreading of waves after passing an edge
Explains patterns seen when waves encounter barriers
When two or more waves meet and combine
Can make bigger waves or cancel them out
Produces patterns of reinforcement and cancellation
The direction in which light waves vibrate
Light whose vibrations are more in one direction than others
Used in sunglasses to block glare
A change in frequency when a source or observer moves
Why a siren sounds higher as it approaches and lower as it passes
Shift in pitch or color caused by relative motion
A wave pattern that stays in one place
Occurs when incoming and reflected waves overlap just right
Shows nodes and antinodes at fixed positions
A point on a standing wave with no motion
Places where the wave amplitude is always zero
Fixed points between vibrating sections
A point on a standing wave with maximum motion
Places where the wave reaches its biggest displacement
Opposite of a node in a vibrating pattern
The ability of a material to return to its shape after stretching
How well something bounces back when forces are removed
Materials with high elasticity stretch and then recover
Force applied over an area inside a material
How strongly the material is being pushed or pulled
Stress can cause materials to change shape or break
How much a material stretches or changes shape
The deformation that results from applied stress
Measured as a change in length divided by original length
A number that describes a material's stiffness
Higher values mean the material is harder to stretch
Found by comparing stress to strain
The ability of a device to store electric charge
Measured in farads and used in capacitors
Determines how much charge a component holds at a given voltage
A property of coils that resists changes in current
Makes a changing current produce a voltage
Measured in henrys and used in inductors
A tiny particle of light
Carries electromagnetic energy like light and radio waves
Has no mass but carries energy and momentum
When an object vibrates strongly at a particular frequency
Occurs when a system is driven at its natural frequency
Can make sounds louder or cause structures to oscillate more
